**G.L. c. 212, \u00a74**.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, §4**, because the acts and omissions giving rise to this action occurred within Berkshire County, Massachusetts, and the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000.

**G.L. c. 214, \u00a71**.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 214, §1**, and personal jurisdiction over the Defendant pursuant to **G.L. c. 223A, §3(a)**, as Defendant resides in this Commonwealth.

**G.L. c. 223A, \u00a73(a)**.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction under **G.L. c. 214, §1**, and personal jurisdiction over the Defendant pursuant to **G.L. c. 223A, §3(a)**, as Defendant resides in this Commonwealth.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a785**.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners have a duty to maintain their premises, including trees and structures adjacent to public ways, in a reasonably safe condition so as not to pose an unreasonable risk of harm to lawful users of the public sidewalk.

**Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 6.proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable injuries resulting from the dangerous condition of the tree branch extending over the sidewalk.
**Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 6.support_reasoning: The case does not involve a tree or a branch overhanging a sidewalk, nor does it impose a duty on the defendant city to address a specific dangerous condition on or immediately adjacent to its land. Instead, the court holds that any potential danger (the railroad tracks across the river) was too remote to justify imposing a landowner’s duty and that, even assuming some duty, the city is shielded by the public duty and discretionary function exceptions. Thus, the opinion undercuts rather than supports a claimed duty of reasonable care for a discrete, nearby hazardous condition like a tree branch over a sidewalk.
**Gage v. Westfield, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 6.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the plaintiffs that in some situations a landowner’s duty to exercise reasonable care does not terminate abruptly at the borders of his property but may extend to include a duty to take safety measures related to known dangers on adjacent property… Given the obviousness of the danger here, however, we doubt that a private landowner in the position of the city would be liable… In the present case, the potential danger… is too remote to justify the imposition of liability on the city based upon the condition of the premises.”

**Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch Sys., I.raw_text: **Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch Sys., Inc., 336 Mass. 268 (1957)**
**Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch Sys., I.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to act despite actual notice of the hazard.
**Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch Sys., I.case_name: Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch System, Inc.
**Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch Sys., I.support_reasoning: The core holding of the majority is that the defendant did not breach any duty to the plaintiff because the defect was not hidden and the plaintiff already knew of the hazard; thus there was no duty to warn or act further. The case therefore rejects liability despite any notice, and is authority against, not for, a proposition that the defendant breached its duty by failing to act despite actual notice of the hazard. The dissent would find a breach on that basis, but it is not the law of the case.
**Hannon v. Hayes-Bickford Lunch Sys., I.relevant_excerpt: “A majority of the court is of the opinion that there was no evidence that the plaintiff was injured by reason of the defendant’s failure to warn him of a hidden defect.… The plaintiff cannot assert that he is entitled to warning of a risk of injury of which he already knew… The action of the trial judge in entering a verdict under leave reserved was correct. In accordance with the terms of the report, judgment is to be entered for the defendant.”

**Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2.proposition: The condition of the tree was open, obvious, and known to Defendant long before the incident; his delay in taking action rendered the harm foreseeable.
**Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2.support_reasoning: The case does address open and obvious conditions and foreseeability, but the facts and holding concern a trampoline–pool setup, not a tree, and there is no discussion of a landowner’s delayed response to a deteriorating natural condition. The opinion holds that even where a danger is open and obvious, a landowner who creates and maintains that danger, knowing people will encounter it, has a duty to remedy it. It does not involve or analyze a situation where a preexisting natural condition (like a tree) became hazardous over time and the owner’s delay in acting rendered harm foreseeable.
**Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (2.relevant_excerpt: “Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool, with a ladder leading directly from the pool to the trampoline, for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool. He knew that the pool warned against jumping of any kind, and he knew that the setup was dangerous but proceeded with the setup because he thought it would be ‘fun.’ … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

**Jardine v. Weem, 347 Mass. 674 (1964)*.proposition: The branch’s collapse and Plaintiff’s resulting injuries were the direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligent maintenance of his property.
**Jardine v. Weem, 347 Mass. 674 (1964)*.case_name: McKenna v. Commissioner of Mental Health
**Jardine v. Weem, 347 Mass. 674 (1964)*.support_reasoning: The case is an employment/mandamus and back pay decision concerning mitigation of damages for a wrongfully discharged public employee. It does not involve premises liability, property maintenance, falling branches, or proximate cause of personal injuries. Therefore it does not provide any authority for the proposition that a collapsing branch and resulting injuries were the direct and proximate result of negligent maintenance of property.
**Jardine v. Weem, 347 Mass. 674 (1964)*.relevant_excerpt: “This is a petition for a writ of mandamus to compel the Commissioner of Mental Health and the superintendent of Cushing Hospital to restore the petitioner to his position at the Cushing Hospital without loss of compensation… In proper circumstances a petitioner can recover back salary incident to a writ of mandamus ordering reinstatement to employment… Our cases have indicated, however, that the employer has the burden of proof on the issue of mitigation of damages.”

**New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker.raw_text: **New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker Corp., 20 Mass. App. Ct. 25 (1985)**
**New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker.proposition: There was no superseding or intervening cause of the injury, as the weather was typical for the season and foreseeable.
**New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker.case_name: New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker Corp.
**New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with UCC warranty accrual, promises to repair, tolling, estoppel, and economic loss in negligence, not with superseding or intervening causation or the foreseeability of weather-related events. Nowhere does the court discuss weather conditions, intervening causes, or superseding causes of injury. Thus this case does not provide authority for the proposition that typical seasonal weather is not a superseding or intervening cause of injury.
**New England Power Co. v. Riley Stoker.relevant_excerpt: The remaining counts of NEP’s amended complaint allege that Riley performed various obligations under the contracts and 1974 agreement negligently. Even assuming (but specifically not concluding) that these claims are not precluded under G. L. c. 260, § 2A, these claims seek relief for economic loss and damage to the boilers, injuries for which there is no recovery. See Marcil v. John Deere Industrial Equip. Co., 9 Mass. App. Ct. 625, 629-632 (1980), and cases cited.

**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constituted a breach of his duty under Restatement (Second) of Torts §364, as adopted in **Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973)**, imposing liability on landowners for conditions on land causing injury to persons lawfully using adjacent ways.
**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is a short concurrence by Justice Kaplan, focused on the treatment of categories of entrants (trespassers, licensees, invitees) and criticizing the majority’s footnote regarding trespassers. It does not mention Restatement (Second) of Torts §364, adjacent ways, or any specific duty to persons lawfully using adjacent public ways. While the *Mounsey* majority opinion may address such duties, this excerpt alone does not establish or adopt §364 or impose liability on that basis, so it cannot be said to support the proposition as framed.
**Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973.relevant_excerpt: I go along with the court but I am taken somewhat aback by footnote 7 which seems unfaithful to the rest of the opinion. The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that “trespassers” stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential.

**Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, \u00a785J**.proposition: Defendant’s negligence directly and proximately caused damages to Plaintiff within the meaning of **Mass. Gen. Laws c. 231, §85J**, authorizing recovery for personal injuries caused by negligence.

**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass.proposition: Under **Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass. 368 (2010)**, the standard of reasonable care supersedes antiquated distinctions regarding natural or artificial conditions; thus Defendant’s failure to act reasonably regarding the tree branch is actionable negligence.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass.support_reasoning: Papadopoulos expressly abolishes the natural/unnatural condition distinction (in that case for snow and ice) and replaces it with a unified reasonable-care standard for premises hazards, holding that owners owe the same duty of reasonable care for such hazards as for any others. While the facts involve ice rather than a tree branch, the opinion’s reasoning is framed broadly as premises liability doctrine, not limited to frozen precipitation, and is routinely cited for the general proposition that outdated categorical distinctions yield to a reasonable-care analysis. Thus, it supports citing reasonable care as the controlling standard for a tree-branch hazard on premises, though it does not specifically mention tree branches.
**Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We now abolish the distinction between natural and unnatural accumulations of snow and ice, and apply to all hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation of reasonable care that a property owner owes to lawful visitors regarding all other hazards… We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to ‘act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances….’”

**Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 20.raw_text: **Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 200 Mass. 303 (1908)**
**Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 20.proposition: See also **Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 200 Mass. 303 (1908)** (foreseeability is key element of duty of care); **Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)** (landowners must anticipate foreseeable risks and take reasonable precautions).
**Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 20.case_name: Sullivan v. Old Colony Street Railway
**Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 20.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss foreseeability as an element of duty of care, nor does it analyze the scope of a landowner or carrier’s duty based on foreseeable risks. Instead, it focuses on (1) the requirement of actual damage to recover for negligence, (2) the proper measure of damages and mitigation, and (3) factual questions about notice and the plaintiff’s own conduct. There is no articulated rule that ‘foreseeability is [a] key element of duty of care’ or that landowners must anticipate foreseeable risks in the sense described by the proposition.
**Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 20.relevant_excerpt: “Although there has been negligence in the performance of a legal duty, yet it is only those who have suffered damage therefrom that may maintain an action therefor… It was a question of fact for the jury whether under the circumstances the defendant had given sufficient notice of what was to be done in the existing emergency… and [the jury] have found that the plaintiff’s exposure and subsequent failure to reach Newport were due to his own acts… rather than to any fault of the defendant.”

**Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mas.proposition: See also **Sullivan v. Old Colony St. Ry. Co., 200 Mass. 303 (1908)** (foreseeability is key element of duty of care); **Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mass. 47 (1983)** (landowners must anticipate foreseeable risks and take reasonable precautions).
**Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted text is from a dissent focusing on causation and the sufficiency of evidence, not on the existence or scope of the landowner’s duty of care or the role of foreseeability in defining that duty. While the dissent briefly mentions foreseeability, it does so only in the context of proximate cause and the specific risks posed by an inadequately secured gate and unlocked refectory, not to articulate the general duty principle attributed in the proposition. Thus, this portion of Mullins does not meaningfully support the claimed statement about landowners’ duty to anticipate foreseeable risks and take reasonable precautions.
**Mullins v. Pine Manor College, 389 Mas.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff had the burden of proving that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiffs safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). The foreseeable risk of an inadequately secured gate is that an intruder might enter the premises for mischievous purposes.

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a76B**.proposition: Award Plaintiff her costs and reasonable interest under **G.L. c. 231, §6B**;
